description: From Middle English liberte, from Old French liberté, from Latin libertas (“freedom”), from liber (“free”); see liberal.

entries.meaning: The condition of being free from control or restrictions.
examples: The army is here, your liberty is assured.

entries.meaning: The condition of being free from imprisonment, slavery or forced labour.
examples: The prisoners gained their liberty from an underground tunnel.

entries.meaning: The condition of being free to act, believe or express oneself as one chooses.
examples: Everyone has the right to life, liberty and security of person.

entries.meaning: A short period when a sailor is allowed ashore.
examples: We're going on a three-day liberty as soon as we dock.

entries.meaning: (often plural) A breach of social convention.
(historical) A local division of government administration in medieval England.
(game of Go) An empty space next to a group of stones of the same color.
